titleStmt.title: The Beggar's Bush1622
titleStmt.author: Beaumont, Francis; Fletcher, John; Massinger, Philip

editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: Is he then taken?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: And brought back even now sir.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: He was not in disgrace?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: No man more loved,
Nor more deserved it, being the only man.
That durst be honest in this court.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: Indeed
We have heard abroad sir, that the state hath suffered,
A great change, since the countess death.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: It hath sir.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: My five years absence, hath kept me a stranger
So much to all the occurrents of my country,
As you shall bind me for some short relation
To make me understand the present times.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I must begin then with a war was made
And seven years with all cruelty continued
Upon our Flanders by the Duke of Brabant,
The cause grew thus: during our Earls minority,
Woolfort, (Who now usurps) was employed thither
To treat about a match between our Earl
And the daughter and heir of Brabant: during which treaty
The Brabander pretends, this daughter was
Stolen from his court, by practice of our state,
Though we are all confirmed, 'twas a sought quarrel
To lay an unjust gripe upon this earldom,
It being here believed the Duke of Brabant
Had no such loss. This war upon't proclaimed,
Our Earl, being then a child, although his father
Good Gerrard lived, yet in respect he was
Chosen by the countess favour, for her husband
And but a gentleman, and Floriz holding
His right unto this country from his mother,
The state thought fit in this defensive war,
Woolfort being then the only man of mark,
To make him general.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: Which place we have heard
He did discharge with honour.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Ay, so long,
And with so blessed successes, that the Brabander
Was forced (His treasures wasted, and the choice
Of his best men of arms tired, or cut off)
To leave the field, and sound a base retreat
Back to his country: but so broken both
In mind and means, ere to make head again,
That hitherto he sits down by his loss,
Not daring, or for honour, or revenge
Again to tempt his fortune. But this victory
More broke our state, and made a deeper hurt
In Flanders, than the greatest overthrow
She ever received: for Woolfort, now beholding
Himself, and actions in the flattering glass
Of self-deservings, and that cherished by
The strong assurance of his power, for then
All captains of the army, were his creatures,
The common soldier too at his devotion,
Made so by full indulgence to their rapines
And secret bounties, this strength too well known
And what it could effect, soon put in practice,
As furthered by the childhood of the Earl
And their improvidence, that might have pierced
The heart of his designs, gave him occasion
To seize the whole, and in that plight you find it.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: Sir, I receive the knowledge of thus much
As a choice favour from you

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Only I must add
Bruges holds out.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: Whether sir, I am going
For there last night I had a ship put in,
And my horse waits me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I wish you a good journey.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: What? Hubert stealing from me? who disarmed him,
It was more than I commanded; take your sword,
I am best guarded with it in your hand,
I have seen you use it nobly.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: And will turn it
On mine own bosom, ere it shall be drawn
Unworthily or rudely.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Would you leave me
Without a farewell Hubert? fly a friend
Unwearied in his study to advance you?
What have I e'er possessed which was not yours?
Or either did not court you to command it?
Whoever yet arrived to any grace,
Reward or trust from me, but his approaches
Whereby your fair reports of him preferred?
And what is more I made myself your servant,
In making you the master of those secrets
Which not the rack of conscience could draw from me,
Nor I, when I asked mercy, trust my prayers with;
Yet after these assurances of love,
These ties and bonds of friendship, to forsake me,
Forsake me as an enemy? come you must
Give me a reason.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, and so I will,
If I may do't in private: and you hear it.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: All leave the room: you have your will, set down
And use the liberty of our first friendship.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Friendship? when you proved traitor first, that vanished
Nor do I owe you any thought, but hate,
I know my flight hath forfeited my head;
And so I may make you first understand
What a strange monster you have made yourself,
I welcome it.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: To me this is strange language.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: To you? why what are you?

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Your prince and master,
The Earl of Flanders.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: By a proper title,
Raised to it by cunning circumvention, force,
Blood, and proscriptions.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: And in all this wisdom;
Had I not reason? when by Gerrard's plots
I should have first been called to a strict account
How, and which way I had consumed that mass
Of money, as they term it in the war,
Who underhand, had by his ministers
Detracted my great action, made my faith
And loyalty so suspected in which failing
He sought my life by practice.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: With what forehead,
Do you speak this to me? who (As I know't)
Must, and will say 'tis false,

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: My guard there.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, you bade me sit, and promised you would hear
Which I now say you shall, not a sound more,
For I that am contemner of mine own,
Am master of your life; then here's a sword
Between you, and all aids sir, though you blind
The credulous beast, the multitude, you pass not
These gross untruths on me.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: How? gross untruths.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Ay, and it is favourable language,
They had been in a mean man lies, and foul ones.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: You take strange licence.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Yes, were not those rumours
Of being called unto your answers, spread
By your own followers; and weak Gerrard wrought
(But by your cunning practice) to be believed
That you were dangerous; yet not to be
Punished by any formal course of law,
But first to be made sure, and have your crimes
Laid open after, which your quaint train taking
You fled unto the camp, and there craved humbly
Protection for your innocent life, and that,
Since you had scaped the fury of the war,
You might not fall by treason, and for proof,
You did not for your own ends make this danger;
Some that had been before, by you suborned,
Came forth and took their oaths they had been hired
By Gerrard to your murder. This once heard,
And easily believed, th'enraged soldier
Seeing no further than the outward man,
Snatched hastily his arms, ran to the court,
Killed all that made resistance, cut in pieces
Such as were servants, or thought friends to Gerrard,
Vowing the like to him.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Will you yet end?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Which he foreseeing, with his son, the Earl,
Forsook the city; and by secret ways
As you give out, and we would gladly have it,
Escaped their fury: though 'tis more than feared
They fell among the rest; nor stand you there
To let us only mourn, the impious means
By which you got it, but your cruelties since
So far transcend your former bloody ills,
As if compared, they only would appear
Essays of mischief; do not stop your ears,
More are behind yet.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: O repeat them not,
'Tis hell to hear them named.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You should have thought,
That hell would be your punishment when you did them,
A prince, in nothing but your princely lusts,
And boundless rapines.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: No more I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Who was the lord of house or land, that stood
Within the prospect of your covetous eye?

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: You are in this to me a greater tyrant,
Then ere I was to any.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I end thus
The general grief, now to my private wrong;
The loss of Gerrard's daughter Jaqueline:
The hoped for partner of my lawful bed,
Your cruelty hath frighted from mine arms;
And her, I now was wand'ring to recover.
Think you that I had reason now to leave you,
When you are grown so justly odious,
That e'en my stay here with your grace and favour,
Makes my life irksome? here surely take it,
And do me but this fruit of all your friendship,
That I may die by you, and not your hangman.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: O Hubert, these your words and reasons have
As well drawn drops of blood from my grieved heart,
As these tears from mine eyes;
Despise them not
By all that's sacred, I am serious Hubert,
You now have made me sensible, what furies,
Whips, hangmen, and tormentors a bad man
Does ever bear about him: let the good
That you this day have done, be ever numbered,
The first of your best actions;
Can you think,
Where Floriz is or Gerrard, or your love,
Or any else, or all that are proscribed?
I will resign, what I usurp, or have
Unjustly forced; the days I have to live
Are too too few to make them satisfaction
With any penitence: yet I vow to practise
All of a man.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: O that your heart and tongue
Did not now differ!

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: By my griefs they do not
Nake the good pains to search them out; 'tis worth it,
You have made clean a leper: trust me you have,
And made me once more fit for the society,
I hope of good men.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, do not abuse
My aptness to believe.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Suspect not you
A faith that's built upon so true a sorrow,
Make your own safeties: ask them all the ties
Humanity can give, Hemskirk too shall
Along with you to this so wished discovery,
And in my name profess all that you promise;
And I will give you this help to't: I have
Of late received certain intelligence,
That some of them are in or about Bruges
To be found out: which I did then interpret,
The cause of that towns standing out against me;
But now am glad, it may direct your purpose
Of giving them their safety, and me peace.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.p: Be constant to your goodness, and you have it. Ex.

div.head: Scaena secunda.

sp.speaker: 1. Merchant
sp.l: 'Tis much that you deliver of this Goswin.

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant
sp.l: But short of what I could, yet have the country
Confirmed it true, and by a general oath,
And not a man hazard his credit in it:
He bears himself with such a confidence
As if he were the master of the sea;
And not a wind upon the sailors compass,
But from one part or other, was his factor,
To bring him in the best commodities,
Merchant e'er ventured for:
'Tis strange,
And yet;
This does in him deserve the least of wonder,
Compared with other his peculiar fashions,
Which all admire: he's young, and rich, at least
Thus far reputed so, that since he lived
In Bruges, there was never brought to harbour
So rich a bottom, but his bill would pass
Unquestioned for her lading.

sp.speaker: 3 merchant
sp.l: Yet he still
Continues a good man.

sp.speaker: 2 merchant
sp.l: So good, that but
To doubt him, would be held an injury
Or rather malice, with the best that traffic;
But this is nothing, a great stock, and fortune,
Crowning his judgement in his undertakings
May keep him upright that way: but that wealth
Should want the power to make him dote on it,
Or youth teach him to wrong it, best commends
His constant temper; for his outward habit
'Tis suitable to his present course of life:
His table furnished well, but not with dainties
That please the appetite only for their rareness,
Or the dear price: nor given to wine or women,
Beyond his health, or warrant of a man,
I mean a good one: and so loves his state
He will not hazard it at play; nor lend
Upon the assurance of a well-penned letter,
Although a challenge second the denial
From such as make th'opinion of their valour
Their means of feeding.

sp.speaker: 1 merchant
sp.l: These are ways to thrive,
And the means not cursed.

sp.speaker: 2 merchant
sp.l: What follows this,
Makes many venturers with him, in their wishes,
For his prosperity: for when desert
Or reason leads him to be liberal,
His noble mind and ready hand contend
Which can add most to his free courtesies,
Or in their worth, or speed to make them so.
Is there a virgin of good fame wants dowry?
He is a father to her; or a soldier
That in his country's service, from the war
Hath brought him only scars, and want? his house
Receives him, and relieves him, with that care
As if what he possessed had been laid up
For such good uses, and he steward of it.
But I should lose myself to speak him further
And stale in my relation, the much good
You may be witness of, if your remove
From Brugis, be not speedy.

sp.speaker: 1 merchant
sp.l: This report
I do assure you will not hasten it,
Nor would I wish a better man to deal with
For what I am to part with.

sp.speaker: 3 merchant
sp.l: Never doubt it,
He is your man and ours, only I wish
His too much forwardness to embrace all bargains
Suck him not in the end.

sp.speaker: 2 merchant
sp.l: Have better hopes,
For my part I am confident; here he comes.

div.stage: Enter Florez and the fourth merchant.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I take it at your own rates: your wine of Cyprus,
But for your Candy sugars, they have met
With such foul weather, and are prized so high
I cannot save in them.

sp.speaker: 4 merchant
sp.l: I am unwilling
To seek another chapman: make me offer
Of something near my price, that may assure me
You can deal for them.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I both can, and will,
But not with too much loss; your bill of lading
Speaks of two hundred chests, valued by you
At thirty thousand gilders. I will have them
At twenty eight; so, in the payment of
Three thousand sterling, you fall only in
Two hundred pound.

sp.speaker: 4 Mar.
sp.l: You know, they are so cheap. —

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why look you; I'll deal fairly, there's in prison,
And at your suit, a pirate, but unable
To make you satisfaction, and past hope
To live a week, if you should prosecute
What you can prove against him: set him free,
And you shall have your money to a stiver,
And present payment.

sp.speaker: 4 Mar.
sp.l: This is above wonder,
A merchant of your rank, that have at sea
So many bottoms in the danger of
These water-thieves, should be a means to save 'em
It more importing you for your own safety
To be at charge to scour the sea of them
Then stay the sword of justice, that is ready
To fall on one so conscious of his guilt
That he dares not deny it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You mistake me,
If you think I would cherish in this captain
The wrong he did to you, or any man;
I was lately with him, (Having first, from others
True testimony been assured, a man
Of more desert never put from the shore)
I read his letters of mart from this state granted
For the recovery of such losses, as
He had received in Spain, 'twas that he aimed at,
Not at three tons of wine, biscuit, or beef,
Which his necessity made him take from you.
If he had pillaged you near, or sunk your ship,
Or thrown your men overboard, than he deserved
The law's extremest rigour: but since want
Of what he could not live without, compelled him
To that he did (Which yet our state calls death)
I pity his misfortune; and to work you
To some compassion of them, I come up
To your own price: save him, the goods are mine;
If not, seek elsewhere, I'll not deal for them.

sp.speaker: 4 Mar.
sp.l: Well sir, for your love, I will once be led
To change my purpose.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For your profit rather.

sp.speaker: 4 Mar.
sp.l: I'll presently make means for his discharge,
Till when, I leave you.

sp.speaker: 2 Mar.
sp.l: What do you think of this?

sp.speaker: 1 Mar.
sp.l: As of a deed of noble pity: guided
By a strong judgement.

sp.speaker: 2 Mar.
sp.l: Save you master Goswin.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Good day to all.

sp.speaker: 2 Mar.
sp.l: We bring you the refusal
Of more commodities.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Are you the owners
Of the ship that lastnight put into the harbour?

sp.speaker: 1 Mar.
sp.l: Both of the ship, and lading.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What's the fraught?

sp.speaker: 3 Mar.
sp.l: And cloth of gold brought from Camball.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Rich lading,
For which I were your chapman, but I am
Already out of cash.

sp.speaker: 1 Mar.
sp.l: I'll give you day
For the moiety of all.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How long?

sp.speaker: 3 merchant
sp.l: Six months.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis a fair offer: which (If we agree
About the prizes) ay, with thanks accept of,
And will make present payment of the rest;
Some two hours hence I'll come aboard.

sp.speaker: 1 merchant
sp.l: The gunner shall speak you welcome.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I'll not fail,

sp.speaker: 3 merchant
sp.l: Good morrow. Exit merch.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Heaven grant my ships a safe return, before
The day of this great payment: as they are
Expected three months sooner: and my credit
Stands good with all the world. Enter Gerrard.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Bless my good master,
The prayers of your poor beadsman ever shall
Be sent up for you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: God 'a mercy clause,
There's something to put thee in mind hereafter
To think of me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: May he that gave it you
Reward you for it, with increase, good master.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I thrive the better for thy prayers.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I hope so.
This three years have I fed upon your bounties,
And by the fire of your blessed charity warmed me,
And yet, good master, pardon me, that must,
Though I have now received your alms, presume
To make one suit more to you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What is't clause?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Yet do not think me impudent I beseech you,
Since hitherto your charity hath prevented
My begging your relief, 'tis not for money
Nor clothes (Good master) but your good word for me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That thou shalt have, clause, for I think thee honest.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Tomorrow then (Dear mr. ) take the trouble
Of walking early unto beggar's bush,
And as you see me, among others (Brothers
In my affliction) when you are demanded
Which you like best among us, point out me,
And then pass by, as if you knew me not.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But what will that advantage thee?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O much sir,
'Twill give me the pre-eminence of the rest,
Make me a King among 'em, and protect me,
From all abuse, such as are stronger, might
Offer my age; sir, at your better leisure
I will inform you further of the good
It may do to me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Troth thou mak'st me wonder;
Have you a King and commonwealth among you?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We have, and there are states are governed worse.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ambition among beggars?

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.l: Many great ones
Would part with half their states, to have the place,
And credit to beg in the first file, master:
But shall I be so much bound to your furtherance
In my petition?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That thou shalt not miss of,
Nor any worldly can make me forget it,
I will be early there.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Heaven bless my master. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Higgen, Ferret, Prig, clause, Jaculine, Snap, gynkes, and other beggars.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Come princes of the ragged regiment,
You o' the blood, Prig my most upright lord,
And these (What name or title, ere they bear)
Jarkman, or Patrico, Cranke, or clapperdudgeon.
Frater, or abram-man; I speak to all
That stand in fair election for the title
Of King of beggars, with the command adjoining,
Higgen, your orator, in this inter-regnum,
That whilom was your dommerer, doth beseech you
All to stand fair, and put yourselves in rank,
That the first comer, may at his first view
Make a free choice, to say up the question.

sp.speaker: Fer. Pr.
sp.l: 'Tis done lord Higgen.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Thanks to prince Prig, prince ferret.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Well, pray my masters all, ferret be chosen
You're like to have a merciful mild prince of me.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: A very tyrant, ay, an arrant tyrant.
If e'er I come to reign; therefore look to't,
Except you do provide me hum enough
And lour to bouze with: I must have my capons
And turkeys brought me in, with my green geese,
And ducklings i'th season: fine fat chickens,
Or if you chance where an eye of tame pheasants
Or partridges are kept, see they be mine,
Or straight I seize on all your privilege,
Places, revenues, offices, as forfeit,
Call in your crutches, wooden legs, false bellies,
Forced eyes and teeth, with your dead arms; not leave you
A dirty clout to beg with of your heads,
Or an old rag with butter, frankincense,
Brimstone and resin, birdlime, blood, and cream,
To make you an old sore; not so much soap
As you may foam with i'th falling-sickness;
The very bag you bear, and the brown dish
Shall be escheated. All your daintiest dells too
I will deflower, and take your dearest doxies
From your warm sides; and than some one cold night
I'll watch you what old barn you go to roost in,
And there I'll smother you all i'th musty hay.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: This is tyrantlike indeed: but what would Ginkes
Or clause be here, if either of them should reign?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Best ask an ass, if he were made a camel,
What he would be; or a dog, and he were a lion.

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: I care not what you are, sirs, I shall be
A beggar, still, I am sure, find myself there.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: O here a judge comes.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Cry, a judge, a judge.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What ail you sirs? what means this out cry?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Master
A sort of poor souls met: God's fools, good master,
Have had some little variance amongst ourselves
Who should be honestest of us; and which lives
Uprightest in his call: now, 'cause we thought
We never should 'gree on't ourselves, because
Indeed 'tis hard to say: we all dissolved, to put it
To whom that should come next, and that's your mastership,
Who, I hope, will termine it as your mind serves you,
Right, and no otherwise we ask it: which?
Which does your worship think is he? sweet master
Look over us all, and tell us; we are seven of us,
Like to the seven wise masters, or the planets.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I should judge this the man with the grave beard,
And if he be not —

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Bless you, good master, bless you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I would he were: there's something too, amongst you
To keep you all honest.Exit

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: King of heaven go with you.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Now good reward him,
May he never want it, to comfort still the poor, in a good hour.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What is't ? see: snap has got it.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: A good crown, marry:

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: A crown of gold.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For our new King: good luck.

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: To the common treasury with it; if 't be gold,
Thither it must.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Spoken like a patriot, ferret —
King clause. I bid God save thee first, first, clause,
After this golden token of a crown;
Where's orator Higgen with his gratuling speech now,
In all our names?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here he is pumping for it.

sp.speaker: Gin.
sp.l: He has coughed the second time, 'tis but once more
And then it comes.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So, out with all: expect now —

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: That thou art chosen, venerable clause,
Our King and sovereign; monarch o'th maunders.
Thus we throw up our nab-cheats, first for joy,
And then our filches; last, we clap our fambles,
Three subject signs, we do it without envy:
For who is he here did not wish thee chosen
Now thou art chosen? ask 'em: all will say so,
Nay swear't: 'tis for the King, but let that pass;
When last in conference at the bousing ken
This other day we sat about our dead prince
Of famous memory: (Rest, go with his rags:)
And that I saw thee at the table's end,
Rise moved, and gravely leaning on one crutch,
Lift the other like a sceptre at my head,
I then presaged thou shortly wouldst be King
And now thou art so: but what need presage,
To us, that might have read it, in thy beard,
As well, as he that chose thee? by that beard
Thou wert found out, and marked for sovereignty.
O happy beard! but happier prince, whose beard,
Was so remarked, as marked out our prince,
Not bating us a hair. Long may it grow,
And thick, and fair, that who lives under it,
May live as safe, as under beggar's bush,
Of which this is the thing, that but the type.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Excellent, excellent orator, forward good Higgen
Give him leave to spit: the fine, well-spoken Higgen.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: This is the beard, the bush, or bushy-beard,
Under whose gold and silver reign 'twas said
So many ages since, we all should smile
On impositions, taxes, grievances,
Knots in a state, and whips unto a subject,
Lie lurking in this beard, but all hemmed out:
If now, the beard be such, what is the prince
That owes the beard? A father; no, a grandfather;
Nay the great grandfather of you his people.
He will not force away your hens, your bacon,
When you have ventured hard for't, nor take from you
The fattest of your puddings: under him
Each man shall eat his own stolen eggs, and butter,
In his own shade, or sunshine, and enjoy
His own dear dell, doxy, or mort, at night
In his own straw, with his own shirt, or sheet,
That he hath filched that day, ay, and possess
What he can purchase, back, or belly-cheats
To his own prop: he will have no purveyors
For pigs, and poultry.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: That we must have, my learned orator,
It is our will, and every man to keep
In his own path and circuit.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Do you hear?
You must hereafter maund on your own pads he says.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And what they get there, is their own, besides
To give good words.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Do you mark? to cut been whids,
That is the second law.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And keep afoot
The humble, and the common phrase of begging,
Lest men discover us.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Yes; and cry sometimes,
To move compassion: sir, there is a table,
That doth command all these things, and enjoins 'em;
Be perfect in their crutches: their feigned plasters,
And their true passports, with the ways to stammer,
And to be dumb, and deaf, and blind, and lame,
There, all the halting paces are set down,
I'th learned language.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thither I refer them,
Those, you at leisure shall interpret to them,
We love no heaps of laws, where few will serve.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: O gracious prince, 'save,'save the good K. clause.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: A song to crown him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Set a sentinel out first.

sp.speaker: Sn.
sp.l: The word?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: A cove comes, and fumbumbis to it. —Strike.

sp.l: Cast our caps and cares away: this is beggar's holiday,
At the crowning of our King, thus we ever dance and sing.
In the world look out and see: where so happy a prince as he?
Where the nation live so free, and so merry as do we?
Be it peace, or be it war, here at liberty we are,
And enjoy our ease and rest; to the field we are not pressed;
Nor are called into the town, to be troubled with the gown.
Hang all offices we cry, and the magistrate too, by;
When the subsidies increased, we are not a penny ceased.
Nor will any go to law, with the beggar for a straw.
All which happiness he brags, he doth owe unto his rags.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: A cove: Fumbumbis.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: To your postures; arm:

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Yonder's the town: I see it.

sp.speaker: Hemsk.
sp.l: There's our danger
Indeed afore us, if our shadows save not.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Bless your good worships:

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: One small piece of money.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Amongst us all poor wretches:

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Blind, and lame,

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: For his sake that gives all.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Pitiful worships;

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: One little doit.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: King, by your leave, where are you?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To buy a little bread,

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: To feed so many
Mouths, as will ever pray for you.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Here be seven of us.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Seven, good master, o remember seven,
Seven blessings.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Remember, gentle worship.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: 'Gainst seven deadly sins,

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And seven sleepers.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: If they be hard of heart, and will give nothing —
Alas, we had not a charity this three days.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: There's amongst you all?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Heaven reward you.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Lord, reward you?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The prince of pity bless thee.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Do I see? or is't my fancy that would have it so?
Ha? 'tis her face: come hither maid.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: What ha', you
Bells for my squirrel? I ha' given Bun meat,
You do not love me, do you? catch me a butterfly,
And I'll love you again; when? can you tell?
Peace, we go a birding: I shall have a fine thing.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Her voice too says the same; but for my head
I would not that her manners, were so changed,
Hear me thou honest fellow; what's this maiden,
That lives amongst you here?

sp.speaker: Gincks.
sp.l: Ao, ao, ao, ao.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: How? nothing but signs?

sp.speaker: Gin.
sp.l: Ao, ao, ao, ao.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: This strange,
I would sane have it her, but not her thus.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: He is deaf, and du-du-dude — dumb sir.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Slid they did all speak plain e'en now methought
Dost thou know this same maid?

sp.speaker: Sn.
sp.l: Why, why, why, why, which, gu, gu, gu, gu, god's fool
She was borne at the barn yonder,
By-be-be-be-be-beggars bush-bo-bo-bush
Her name is, My-my-my-my-my-match: so was her mo-mo-mo-mothers too-too

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I understand no word she says; how long
Has she been here?

sp.speaker: Sn.
sp.p: Lo-lo-long enough to be niggled: and she ha' go-go-go-good luck,

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I must be better informed, then by this way.
Here was another face too, that I marked
O the old man's: but they are vanished all
Most suddenly: I will come here again,
Oh, that I were so happy, as to find it,
What I yet hope? it is put on.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What mean you sir,
To stay there with that stammerer?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Farewell friend, —
It will be worth return, to search: come,
Protect us our disguise now, prithee hemskirck
If we be taken, how dost thou imagine
This town will use us, that hath stood so long
Out, against Woolfort?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: E'en to hang us forth
Upon their walls a sunning, to make crow's meat,
If I were not assured o' the burgomaster,
And had a pretty skuys, to see a niece there,
I should scarce venture.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Come 'tis now too late
To look back at the ports: good luck, and enter. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Still blowest thou there? and from all other parts,
Do all my agents sleep? that nothing comes?
There's a conspiracy of winds, and servants:
If not of elements, to ha' me break;
What should I think unless the seas, and sands
Had swallowed up my ships? or fire had spoiled
My warehouses? or death devoured my facto
I must ha' had some returns;

sp.speaker: 1. Merchant
sp.l: 'Save you sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Save you.

sp.speaker: 1. Merchant
sp.l: No news, yet o' your ships?

sp.speaker: O.
sp.l: Not any yet sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Merchant
sp.l: 'Tis strange.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis true sir: what a voice was here now?
This was one passing bell, a thousand ravens
Sung in that man now, to presage my ruins.

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant
sp.p: Goswin, good day, these winds, are very constant.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: They are so sir; to hurt —

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant
sp.l: Ha? you had no letters,
Lately from England, nor from Denmark?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant
sp.l: This wind brings them; nor no news over land,
Through Spain, from the straits?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Not any.

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant
sp.l: I am sorry sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: They talk me down: and as 'tis said, of vultures
They sent a field fought, and do smell the carcases
By many hundred miles: so do these, my wracks
At greater distances: why thy will heaven
Come on, and be: yet if thou please, preserve me;
But in my own adventure, here at home,
Of my chaste love, to keep me worthy of her,
It shall be put in scale against all ill fortunes:
I am not broken yet: nor should I fall,
Methinks with less than that, that ruins all.Exit

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter. Van-donck. Hubert. Hemskirck. and Margaret. Boores.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Captain you are welcome; so is this your friend
Most safely welcome, though our town stand out
Against your master; you shall find good quarter:
The troth is, we not love him: Meg: some wine,
Let's talk a little treason, if we can
Talk treason, gain'the traitors; by your leave, gentlemen
We here in Brugis, think he does usurp,
And therefore I am bold with him.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, your boldness,
Happily becomes your mouth, but not our ears,
While we are his servants; and as we come here,
Not to ask questions, walk forth on your walls;
Visit your courts of guard, view your munition,
Ask of your corn-provisions, nor inquire
Into the least, as spies upon your strengths,
So let's entreat, we may receive from you
Nothing in passage or discourse, but what
We may with gladness, and our honesties here,
And that shall seal our welcome.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Good: let's drink then,

sp.speaker: Mage:
sp.l: Fill out, I keep mine old pearl still captain.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I hang fast man.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Old jewels, commend their keeper, sir.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Here's to you with a heart, my captain's friend,
With a good heart, and if this make us speak
Bold words, anon: 'tis all under the rose
Forgotten: drown all memory, when we drink

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: 'Tis freely spoken noble burgomaster,
I'll do you right.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Nay sir mine heir Van-donck,
Is a true statesmen.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Fill my captain's cup there, o that your master Woolfort.
Had been an honest man.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Under the rose.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Here's to you Margot.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Welcome; welcome captain.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Well said my pearl still,

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Well said, my pearl still,

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: And how does my niece?
Almost a woman; I think? This friend of mine,
I drew along with me, through so much hazard,
Only to see her: she was my errand.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Ay, a kind uncle you are (Fill him his glass)
That in seven years, could not find leisure. —

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No,
It's not so much.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: I'll bate you never an hour on't,
I was before the Brabander 'gan his war,
For moonshine, i'th water there, his daughter
That never was lost: yet you could not find time
To see a kinswoman: but she is worth the seeing sir.
Now you are come, you ask if she were a woman?
She is a woman sir; fetch her forth Margee. Exit Marg.
And a fine woman, and has suitors.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: How?
What suitors are they.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Bachelors: young burghers:
And one, a gallant, the young prince of merchants,
We call him here, in Bruges.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: How? A merchant?
I thought Vandonck, you had understood me better,
And my niece too, so trusted to you by me:
Than t'admit of such in name of suitors.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Such? he is such a such, as were she mine
I'd give him thirty thousand crowns with her.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.p: But the same things sir, fit not you and me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Why, give's some wine, then; this will fit us all:
Here's to you still, my captain's friend: all out:
And still, would Woolfort were an honest man,
Under the rose, I speak it: but this merchant
Is a brave boy: he lives so, i'the town here,
We know not what to think on him: at sometimes
We fear he will be bankrupt; he does stretch
Tenter his credit so; embraces all,
And to't, the winds have been contrary, long.
But then, if he should have all his returns,
We think he would be a King, and are half sure on't.
Your master is a traitor, for all this
Under the rose: here's to you; and usurps
The earldom from a better man.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I marry sir,
Where is that man?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Nay soft: and I could tell you
'Tis ten to one I would not: here's my hand,
I love not Woolfort: sit you still, with that:
Here comes my captain again, and his fine niece,
And there's my merchant: view him well, fill wine here.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You must not only know me for your uncle,
Now, but obey me; you, go cast yourself
Away, upon a dunghill here? A merchant?
A petty fellow? one that makes this trade
With oaths and perjuries?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What is that you say sir?
If it be me you speak of; as your eye
Seems to direct: I wish you would speak to me, sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Sir, I do say, she is no merchandise,
Will that suffice you?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Merchandise good sir,
Though ye be kinsman to her: take no leave thence
To use me with contempt: I ever thought
Your niece above all price.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: And do so still, sir,
I assure you, her rate's at more than you are worth.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You do not know, what a gentleman's worth sir,
Nor can you value him.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Well said merchant.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Nay,
Let him alone, and ply your matter.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: A gentleman?
What, of the woolpack? or the sugar-chest?
Or lists of velvet? which is't? pound, or yard,
You vent your gentry by?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: O Hemskirk, fie.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Come, do not mind 'em drink, he is no Woolfort,
Captain, I advise you.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Alas, my pretty man,
I think't be angry, by its look: come hither,
Turn this way, a little: if it were the blood
Of Charlemagne, as 't may (For ought I know)
Be some good butchers issue, here in Bruges.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Nay: I'm not certain of that; of this I am,
If it once buy, and sell, its gentry is gone.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ha, ha:

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You are angry, though ye laugh.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No, now 'tis pity
Of your poor argument. Do not you, the lords,
Of land (If you be any) sell the grass,
The corn, the straw, the milk, the cheese?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: And butter:
Remember butter; do not leave out butter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: The beefs and muttons that your grounds are stored with?
Swine, with the very mast, beside the woods?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No, for those sordid uses, we have tenants,
Or else our bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Have not we sir, chapmen,
And factors, than to answer these? your error
Fetched from the heralds a b c. and said over
With your court faces, once an hour, shall never
Make me mistake myself. Do not your lawyers
Sell all their practice, as your priests their prayers?
What is not bought, and sold? The company
That you had last, what had you fort, i'faith?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You now grow saucy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sure I have been bred
Still, with my honest liberty, and must use it.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Upon your equals, then.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sir, he that will
Provoke me first, doth make himself my equal.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Do ye hear? no more.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes sir, this little, I pray you,
An't shall be aside, then after, as you please,
You appear the uncle, sir, to her I love,
More than mine eyes; and I have heard your scorns
With so much scoffing, and so much shame,
As each strive which is greater: but, believe me
I sucked not in this patience with my milk.
Do not presume, because you see me young,
Or cast despites on my profession
For the civility and tameness of it.
A good man bears a contumely worse
Than he would do an injury. Proceed not
To my offence: wrong is not still successful,
Indeed it is not: I would approach your kinswoman
With all respect, done to yourself and her.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Away companion: handling her? take that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Nay, I do love no blows, sir, there's exchange.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Hold sir,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O murder.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Help, my Goswin.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Man.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Let 'em alone; my life for one.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Nay come
If you have will.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: None to offend you, ay, sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He that had, thank himself: not hand her? yes sir,
And clasp her, and embrace her; and (Would she
Now go with me) bear her through all her race,
Her father, brothers, and her uncles, armed,
And all their nephews, though they stood a wood
Of pikes, and wall of cannon: kiss me Gertrude,
Quake not, but kiss me.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Kiss him, girl, I bid you;
My merchant royal; fear no uncles: hang 'em,
Hang up all uncles: are we not in Bruges?
Under the rose here?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: In this circle, love,
Thou are as safe, as in a tower of brass;
Let such as do wrong, fear.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Ay, that's good,
Let Woolfort look to that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sir, here she stands,
Your niece, and my beloved. One of these titles
She must apply to; if unto the last,
Not all the anger can be sent unto her,
In frown, or voice, or other art, shall force her,
Had Hercules a hand in't: come, my joy,
Say thou art mine, aloud love, and profess it.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Do: and I drink to it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Prithee say so, love.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Twould take away the honour from my blushes:
Do not you play the tyrant, sweet: they speak it.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I thank you niece.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sir, thank her for your life,
And fetch your sword within.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You insult too much
With your good fortune, sir. Exit Florez.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: A brave clear spirit;
Hemskirk, you were too blame: a civil habit
Oft covers a good man: and you may meet
In person of a merchant, with a soul
As resolute, and free, and all ways worthy,
As else in any file of mankind: pray you,
What meant you so to slight him?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: 'Tis done now,
Ask no more of it; I must suffer. Exit Hemskirk.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: This,
Is still the punishment of rashness, sorrow;
Well; I must to the woods, for nothing here
Will be got out. There, I may chance to learn
Somewhat to help my inquiries further.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Ha?
A looking-glass.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: How now, brave burgomaster?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I love no Woolforts, and my names Vandonck,

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Van-donck it's rather: come, go sleep within.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Earl Florez is right heir, and this same Woolfort
Under the rose I speak it. —

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Very hardly.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Usurps: and a rank traitor, as ever breathed,
And all that do uphold him. Let me go,
No man shall hold me, that upholds him;
Do you uphold him?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Then hold me up. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Sir, I presume, you have a sword of your own,
That can so handle another's.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Faith you may sir.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: And ye have made me have so much better thoughts of you
As I am bound to call you forth.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For what sir?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: To the repairing of mine honour, and hurt here.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Express your way.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: By fight, and speedily.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You have your will: require you any more?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: That you be secret: and come single.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: As you are the gentleman you would be thought.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Without the conjuration: and I'll bring
Only my sword, which I will fit to yours,
I'll take his length within.

sp.speaker: Hem
sp.l: Your place now sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: By the sand-hills.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Sir, nearer to the woods,
If you thought so, were fitter.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: There, then.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Good.
Your time?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Betwixt seven and eight.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You'll give me sir
Cause to report you worthy of my niece,
If you come, like your promise.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If I do not
Let no man think to call me unworthy first,
I'll do't myself: and justly wish to want her. —Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.p: Come, English beer hostess, English beer byth' belly

sp.speaker: 2 B.
sp.l: Start beer boy, stout and strong beer: so, sit down lads,
And drink me upsey-dutch:
Frolic, and fear not.

body.stage: Enter Higgen like a sowgelder, singing.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Have ye any work for the sowgelder, boam,
My horn goes to high to low, to high to low.
Have ye any pigs, calves, or colts,
Have ye any lambs in your holts
To cut for the stone
Here comes a cunning one.
Have ye any branches to spade,
Or e'er a fair maid
That would be a nun,
Come kiss me, 'tis done.
Hark how my merry born doth blow,
Too high too low, too high too low.

sp.speaker: 1 b.
sp.l: O excellent! twopence a piece boys, twopence a piece:
Give the boys some drink there. Piper, wet your whistle.
Canst tell me a way now, how to cut off my wife's concupiscence?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I'll sing ye a song for't.

body.head: The song.
body.l: And turn her and tug her,
And turn her again boy, again,
Than her disease no longer will reign.
And once a day swinge her again
If she stand all these pains
Her disease no longer will reign.

sp.speaker: 1 bo.
sp.l: More excellent, more excellent, sweet sowgelder.

sp.speaker: 2 bo.
sp.l: Threepence a piece, threepence a piece.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Will you hear a song how the devil was gelded?

sp.speaker: 3 bo.
sp.l: Ay, ay, let's hear the devil roar, sowgelder.

sp.speaker: 1 bo.
sp.l: Groats a piece, groats a piece, groats a piece,
There sweet sowgelder.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Will ye see any feats of activity,
Some sleight of hand, legerdemain? heigh pass,
Presto, be gone there?

sp.speaker: 2 bo.
sp.l: Sit down juggler.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Sirrah, play you your art well; draw near piper:
Look you, my honest friends, you see my hands;
Plain dealing is no devil: lend me some money;
Twelvepence a piece will serve.

sp.speaker: 1. 2. B.
sp.l: There, there.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: I thank you,
Thank ye heartily: when shall I pay ye?

sp.speaker: All B.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, by'th mass this was a fine trick.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: A merry sleight toy: but now I'll show your worships
A trick indeed.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Mark him well now my masters.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Here are three balls,
These balls shall be three bullets,
One, two, and three: ascentibus malentibus.
Presto, be gone: they are vanished: fair play gentlemen,
Now these three, like 3. bullets, from your three noses
Will I pluck presently: fear not, no harm boys,
Titere, tu patule.

sp.speaker: 1 b.
sp.l: O, o, o.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Recubans sub jermine fagi.

sp.speaker: 2 b.
sp.l: Ye pull too hard; ye pull too hard.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Stand fair then:
Silvertramtrim-tram.

sp.speaker: 3 b.
sp.l: Hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Prig
sp.l: Come aloft bullets three, with a whim-wham:
Have ye their moneys?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: 1 b.
sp.l: O rare juggler.

sp.speaker: 2 b.
sp.l: O admirable juggler,

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: One trick more yet;
Heigh, come aloft: sa, sa, flim, flum, taradumbis?
East, West, North, South, now fly like Jack with a bumbis.
Now all your money's gone: pray search your pockets.

sp.speaker: 1 b.
sp.l: Humh.

sp.speaker: 2 b.
sp.l: He,

sp.speaker: 3 b.
sp.l: The devil a penny's here.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: This was a rare trick.

sp.speaker: 1 b.
sp.l: But 'twould be a far rarer to restore it.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: I'll do ye that too: look upon me earnestly,
And move not any ways your eyes from this place,
This button here: pow, whirr, whiss, shake your pockets

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: By'th mass 'tis here again boys.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Rest ye merry;
My first trick has paid me.

sp.speaker: All B.
sp.l: Ay, take it, take it,
And take some drink too.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Not a drop now I thank you;
Away, we are discovered else. Exit.

sp.stage: Enter Gerrard like a blind aquavitae-man, and a boy singing the song.
sp.l: Bring out your coney-skins, fair maids to me,
And hold 'em fair that I may see;
Grey, black, and blew: for your smaller skins,
I'll give ye looking-glasses, pins.
And for your whole coney, here's ready ready money.
Come gentle Joan, do thou begin
With thy black, black, black coney-skin.
And marry then, and Jane will follow,
With their silver-haired skins, and their yellow.
The white coney-skin, I will not lay by,
For though it be faint, 'tis fair to the eye,
The grey it is warm, but yet for my money,
Give me the bonny, bonny black coney.
Come away fair maids, your skins will decay:
Come, and take money maids, put your ware away.
Coney-skins, coney-skins, have ye any coney-skins,
I have fine bracelets, and fine silver pins.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Buy any brand wine, buy any brand wine?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Have ye any coney-skins.

sp.speaker: 2 b.
sp.l: My fine canary-bird, there's a cake for thy worship,

sp.speaker: 1 b.
sp.l: Come, fill, fill, fill, fill suddenly: let's see sir,
What's this?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: A penny sir.

sp.speaker: 1 b.
sp.l: Fill till't be sixpence,
And there's my pig.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: This is a counter sir.

sp.speaker: 1 b.
sp.l: A counter? stay ye, what are these then?
O execrable juggler! O damned juggler!
Look in your hose, hoa: this comes of looking forward.

sp.speaker: 3 b.
sp.l: Devil a dunkirk! what a rogue's this juggler,
This hay pass, repass, has repast us sweetly.

sp.speaker: 2 b.
sp.l: Do ye call these tricks.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Have ye any ends of gold or silver.

sp.speaker: 2 b.
sp.l: This fellow comes to mock us; gold or silver? cry copper.

sp.speaker: 1 b.
sp.l: Yes my good friend,
We have e'en an end of all we have.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: 'Tis well sir,
You have the less to care for: gold and silver,Exit.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Have ye any old cloaks to sell, have ye any old cloaks to sell. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 b.
sp.l: Cloaks? look about ye boys: mine's gone.

sp.speaker: 2 b.
sp.l: A — juggle 'em?
— of their prestoes: mine's gone too.

sp.speaker: 3 b.
sp.l: Here's mine yet.

sp.speaker: 1 b.
sp.l: Come, come, let's drink then: more brand wine.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: 1 b.
sp.l: If e'er I catch your sowgelder, by this hand I'll strip him;
Were ever fools so firked? we have two cloaks yet,
And all our caps; the devil take the flincher.

sp.speaker: All B.
sp.l: Yaw, yaw, yaw, yaw.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Good do'n my honest fellows,
You are merry here I see.

sp.speaker: 3 b.
sp.l: 'Tis all we have left sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What hast thou? Aquavitae?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Fill out then,
And give these honest fellows round.

sp.speaker: All b.
sp.l: We thank ye.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: May I speak a word in private to ye?

sp.speaker: All b.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I have a business for you, honest friends,
If you dare lend your help, shall get you crowns.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ha?
Lead me a little nearer, boy.

sp.speaker: 1 b.
sp.l: What is't sir?
If it be any thing to purchase money,
Which is our want, command us.

sp.speaker: Boors.
sp.l: All, all, all sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You know the young spruce merchant in Brugis.

sp.speaker: 2 b.
sp.l: Who? Master Goswin?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: That: he owes me money,
And here in town there is no stirring of him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Say ye so?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: This day, upon a sure appointment,
He meets me a mile hence, by the chase side
Under the row of Okes, do you know it?

sp.speaker: All b.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Give 'em more drink: there if you dare but venture
When I shall give the word to seize upon him,
Here's twenty pound.

sp.speaker: 3 boy.
sp.l: Beware the juggler.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: If he resist, down with him, have no mercy.

sp.speaker: 1 boy.
sp.l: I warrrant you: we'll hamper him.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: To discharge you,
I have a warrant here about me.

sp.speaker: 3 boy.
sp.l: Here's our warrant,
This carries fire i'the tail.

sp.speaker: H●m.
sp.l: Away with me then,
The time draws on,
I must remove so insolent a suitor,
And if he be so rich, make him pay ransom
Ere he see Bruges towers again: thus wise men
Repair the hurts they take by a disgrace,
And piece the lion's skin with the fox's case.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I am glad I have heard this sport yet.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: There's for thy drink; come pay the house within boys,
And lose no time.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Away with all our haste too. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No wind blow fair yet? no return of moneys?
Letters? nor any thing, to hold my hopes up?
Why then 'tis destined, that I fall, fall miserably,
My credit I was built on, sinking with me.
Thou boisterous northwind, blowing my misfortunes,
And frosting all my hopes to cakes of coldness,
Yet stay thy fury: give the gentle South
Yet leave to court those sails that bring me safety,
And you auspicious fires, bright twins in heaven
Dance on the shrowds: he blows still, stubbornly,
And on his boisterous rack rides my sad ruin;
There is no help, there can be now no comfort,
Tomorrow with the sunset sets my credit.
O misery! thou curse of man, thou plague,
In the midst all our strength thou strikest us;
My virtuous love is tossed too: all, what I have been,
No more hereafter to be seen then shadow;
To prison now? well, yet there's this hope left me,
I may sink fairly under this days venture
And so tomorrow's crossed, and all those curses:
Yet manly I'll invite my fate, base fortune
Shall never say, she has cut my throat in fear.
This is the place his challenge called me too,
And was a happy one at this time for me,
For let me fall before my foe i'the field,
And not at bar, before my creditors,
Has kept his word: now sir, your sword's tongue only
Loud as you dare, all other language —

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Well sir,
You shall not be long troubled: draw.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis done sir,
And now have at ye.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Now.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Betrayed to villains?
Slaves ye shall buy me bravely,
And thou base coward.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now upon 'em bravely,
Conjure 'em soundly boys.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Lay on still,
Down with that gentleman rogue, swinge him to syrup:
Retire sir, and take breath: follow and take him,
Take all, 'tis lawful prize.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: We yield.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Down with 'em
Into the wood, and rifle 'em, tew 'em, swinge 'em,
Knock me their brains into their breeches. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Boors.
sp.l: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What these men are I know not, nor for what cause
They should thus thrust themselves into my danger,
Can I imagine. But sure heaven's hand was in't,
Nor why this coward knave should deal so basely
To eat me up with slaves: but heaven, I thank thee,
I hope thou hast reserved me to an end
Fit for thy creature, and worthy of thine honour:
Would all my other dangers here had suffered,
With what a joyful heart should I go home then?
Where now, heaven knows, like him that waits his sentence
Or hears his passing bell; but there's my hope still.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Blessing upon you master.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thank ye; leave me,
For by my troth I have nothing now to give thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Indeed I do not ask sir, only it grieves me
To see ye look so sad; now goodness keep ye
From troubles in your mind.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If I were troubled
What could thy comfort do? prithee clause, leave me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Good master be not angry; for what I say
Is out of true love to ye ..

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I know thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Good Mr. blame that love then, if I prove so saucy
To ask ye why ye are sad.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Most true, I am so,
And such a sadness I have got will sink me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Heaven shield it, sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Faith thou must lose thy master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I had rather lose my neck sir: would I knew —

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What would the knowledge do thee good, so miserable,
Thou canst not help thyself? when all my ways
Nor all the friends I have —

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You do not know sir,
What I can do: cures sometimes, for men's cares
Flow, where they least expect 'em.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I know thou wouldst do,
But farewell clause, and pray for thy poor master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I will not leave ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I dare not leave ye,
And till ye beat me dead, I must not leave ye.
By what ye hold most precious, by heaven's goodness,
As your fair youth may prosper, good sir tell me:
My mind believes yet something's in my power
May ease you of this trouble.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will tell thee
For a hundred thousand crowns upon my credit,
Taken up of merchants to supply my traffics,
The winds and weather envying of my fortune,
And no return to help me off, yet showing
Tomorrow, clause, tomorrow, which must come
In spron, thou shalt find me poor, and broken.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I cannot blame your grief sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Now, what say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I say you should not shrink, for he that gave ye,
Can give you more; his power can bring ye off sir,
When friends and all forsake ye, yet he sees you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That's all my hope.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Hope still sir, are you tide
Within the compass of a day, good master,
To pay this mass of money?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: E'en tomorrow;
But why do I stand mocking of my misery?
Is't not enough the floods, and friends forget me?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Will no less serve?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What if it would?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Your patience,
I do not ask to mock ye: 'tis a great sum,
A sum for mighty men to start, and stick at;
But not for honest: have ye no friends left ye,
None that have felt your bounty? worth this duty?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Duty? thou knowest it not.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It is a duty,
And as a duty, from those men have felt ye,
Should be returned again: I have gained by ye,
A daily almes these seven years you have showered me,
Will half supply your want.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why dost thou fool me?
Canst thou work miracles?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To save my master,
I can work this.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou wilt make me angry with thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: For doing good?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What power hast thou?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Inquire not:
So I can do it, to preserve my master;
Nay if it be three parts.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O that I had it,
But good clause, talk no more, I feel thy charity,
As thou has felt mine: but alas!

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Distrust not.
'Tis that that quenches ye: pull up your spirit,
Your good, your honest, and your noble spirit;
For if the fortunes often thousand people
Can save ye, rest assured; you have forgotten sir,
The good ye did, which was the power you gave me;
Ye shall now know the King of beggar's treasure:
And let the winds blow as they please, the seas roar,
Yet, here tomorrow, you shall find your harbour,
Here fail me not, for if I live I'll fit ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How fain I would believe thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: If I lie master,
Believe no man hereafter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will try thee,
But he knows, that knows all.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Know me tomorrow,
And if I know not how to cure ye, kill me;
So pass in peace, my best, my worthiest master. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena tertia.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Thus have I stolen away disguised from hemskirck
To try these people, for my heart yet tells me
Some of these beggars, are the men I look for
Appearing like myself, they have no reason
(Though my intent is fair, my main end honest)
But to avoid me narrowly, that face too,
That woman's face, how near it is: o may it
But prove the same, and fortune how I'll bless thee;
Thus, sure they cannot know me, or suspect me,
If to my habit I but change my nature;
As I must do; this is the wood they live in,
A place fit for concealment: where, till fortune
Crown me with that I seek, I'll live amongst 'em. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Higgen. Prig. Ferret. Gynks. and the rest of the boors.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Come bring 'em out, for here we sit in justice:
Give to each one a cudgel, a good cudgel:
And now attend your sentence, that you are rogues,
And mischievous base rascals, (There's the point now)
I take it, is confessed.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Deny it if you dare knaves.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: We are rogues sir.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: To amplify the matter then rogues as ye are,
And lambed, ye shall be ere we leave ye.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And to the open handling of our justice,
Why did ye this upon the proper person
Of our good master? were you drunk when you did it?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Yes indeed were we.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: You shall be beaten sober.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Was it for want you undertook it?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: You shall be swinged abundantly.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And yet for all that,
You shall be poor rogues still.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Has not the gentleman,
Pray mark this point brother Prig, that noble gentleman
Relieved ye often, found ye means to live by,
By employing some at sea, some here; some there;
According to your callings?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: 'Tis most true sir.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Is not the man, an honest man?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Yes truly.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: A liberal gentleman? and as ye are true rascals
Tell me but this, have ye not been drunk, and often,
At his charge?

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: Often, often.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: There's the point then,
They have cast themselves, brother Prig.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: A shrewd point brother.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Brother, proceed you now; the cause is open,
I am some what weary.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Can you do these things?
You most abominable stinking rascals,
You turnip-eating rogues.

sp.speaker: Boores.
sp.l: We are truly sorry.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Knock at your hard hearts rogues, and presently
Give us a sign you feel compunction,
Every man up with's cudgel, and on his neighbour
Bestow such alms, till we shall say sufficient,
For there your sentence lies without partiality;
Either of head, or hide, rogues, without sparing,
Or we shall take the pains to beat you dead else:
You shall know your doom.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: One, two, and three about it.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: That fellow in the blue, has true compunction,
He beats his fellows bravely, o, well struck boys,

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Up with that blue breech, now plays he the devil,
So get ye home, drink small beer, and be honest;
Call in the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Do, bring him presently,
His cause I'll hear myself.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Prig. With all due reverence,
We do resign sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now huffing sir, what's your name?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What's that to you sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It shall be ere we part.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: My name is Hemskirk,
I follow the Earl, which you shall feel.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: No threatening,
For we shall cool you sir; why didst thou basely
Attempt the murder of the merchant Goswin ?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What power hast thou to ask me?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I will know it.
Or flay thee till thy pain discover it.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: He did me wrong, base wrong.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: That cannot save ye,
Who sent ye hither? and what further villainies
Have ye in hand?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Why wouldst thou know? what profit,
If I had any private way, could rise
Out of my knowledge, to do thee commodity?
Be sorry for what thou hast done, and make amends fool
I'll talk no further to thee: nor these rascals.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Tie him to that tree.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I have told you whom I follow.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: The devil you should do, by your villainies,
Now he that has the best way, wring it from him.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I undertake it: turn him to the sun boys;
Give me a fine sharp rush, will ye confess yet?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Ye have robbed me already, now you'll murder me

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Murder your nose a little: does your head purge sir?
To it again, 'twill do ye good.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: O,
I cannot tell you any thing.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Proceed then.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: There's maggots in your nose, I'll fetch 'em out sir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: O my head breaks.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The best thing for the rheum sir,
That falls into your worship's eyes.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Speak then.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I know not what.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: It lies in is brain yet,
In lumps it lies, I'll fetch it out the finest;
What pretty faces the fool makes? heigh!

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Hold,
Hold, and I'll tell ye all, look in my doublet;
And there within the lining in a paper,
You shall find all.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Go fetch that paper hither,
And let him lose for this time.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Good e'en my honest friends.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Good e'en good fellow.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: May a poor huntsman, with a merry heart,
A voice shall make the forest ring about him,
Get leave to live amongst ye? true as steel, boys?
That knows all chases, and can watch all hours,
And with my quarter staff, though the devil bid stand,
Deal such an alms, shall make him roar again?
Prick ye the fearful hare through cross ways, sheep walks
And force the crafty Reimald climb the quicksets;
Rouse ye the lofty stag, and with my bell-horn,
Ring him a knell, that all the woods shall mourn him,
Till in his funeral tears, he fall before me?
The polecat, marten, and the rich skinned Lucerne,
I know to chase, the roe, the wind outstripping
Isgrin himself, in all his bloody anger;
I can beat from the bay, and the wild sounder
Single, and with my armed staff, turn the boar,
Spite of his foamy tusks, and thus strike him;
Till he fall down my feast.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: A goodly fellow.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: What mak'st thou here, ha?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We accept thy fellowship.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.p: Hemskirck, thou art not right I fear, I fear thee.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here is the paper: and as he said we found it.

sp.speaker: Ger,
sp.l: Give me it, I shall make a shift yet, old as I am
To find your knavery: you are sent here, sirrah
To discover certain gentlemen, a spy-knave
And if ye find 'em, if not by persuasion
To bring 'em back, by poison to dispatch 'em.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: By poison, ha?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Here is another, Hubert;
What is that Hubert sir?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: You may perceive there.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I may perceive a villainy and a rank one,
Was he joined partner of thy knavery?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No.
He had an honest end, would I have had so,
Which makes him scape such cut throats.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So it seems,
For here thou art commanded, when that Hubert
Has done his best and worthiest service, this way
To cut his throat, for here he's set down dangerous.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: This is most impious.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I am glad we have found ye,
Is not this true?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Yes? what are you the better;

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You shall perceive sir, ere you get your freedom:
Take him aside, and friend, we take thee to us,
Into our company, thou dar'st be true unto us?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Ay, and obedient too?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: As you had bred me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Then take our hand: thou art now a servant to us,
Welcome him all.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Stand off, stand off: I'll do it,
We bid ye welcome three ways; first for your person,
Which is a promising person, next for your quality,
Which is a decent, and a gentle quality,
Last for the frequent means you have to feed us,
You can steal 'tis to be presumed.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Yes, venison,
Or if I want —

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: 'Tis well you understand right,
And shall learn daily: you can drink too?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Soundly.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And ye dare know a woman from a weathercock?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Yes, if I handle her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now swear him.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: You are welcome brother.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Welcome, welcome, welcome, but who shall have the keeping
Of this fellow?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Thank ye friends,
And I beseech ye, if you dare but trust me;
For if I have kept wild dogs and beasts for wonder,
And made 'em tame too: give into my custody
This roaring rascal I shall hamper him,
With all his knacks and knaveries, and I fear me
Discover yet a further villainy in him;
Oh he smells rank oth' rascal.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Take him to thee,
But if he scape —

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Let me be e'en hanged for him,
Room sir, I'll tie ye to my leash.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: A way rascal.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Be not so stubborn: I shall swinge ye soundly,
And ye play tricks with me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now swear him.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I crown thy nab, with a gag of benbouse,
And stall thee by the salmon into the clowes,
To manned on the pad, and strike all the cheats;
To mill from the Ruffmans, commission and states,
Twang dells, i' the stiromell, and let the choir cuffin:
And Herman beck strine, and trine to the ruffian.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now interpret this unto him.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I pour on thy pate a pot of good ale,
And by the rogue's oath a rogue thee install:
To beg on the way, to rob all thou meets;
To steal from the hedge, both the shirt and the sheets:
And lie with thy wench in the straw till she twang,
Let the constable, justice, and devil go hang.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So, now come in,
But ever have an eye sir, to your prisoner.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: He must blind both mine eyes, if he get from me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Go, get some victuals, and some drink, some good drink
For this day we'll keep holly to good fortune,
Come and be frolic with us.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Ye are a stranger. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Indeed you're welcome: I have heard your scape,
And therefore give her leave, that only loves you;
(Truly and dear loves ye) give her joy leave,
To bid ye welcome: what is't makes you sad man?
Why do you look so wild? is 't I offend ye?
Be shrew my heart, not willingly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No Jertred.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Is't the delay of that ye 'Long have looked for,
A happy marriage? now I come to urge it:
Now when ye please to finish it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No news yet?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Do you hear sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Do you love me?

sp.speaker: Flo ..
sp.l: Have I lived,
In all the happiness fortune could seat me,
In all men's fair opinions?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I have provided
A priest, that's ready for us.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: And can the devil,
In one ten days, that devil chance devour me?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: We'll fly to what place you please.

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.l: No star prosperous?
All at a swoop?

sp.speaker: Ber:
sp.l: You do not love me Goswin?
You will not look upon me?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Can men's prayers
Shot up to heaven, with such a zeal as mine are,
Fall back like lazy mists, and never prosper?
Geyves, I must wear, and cold must be my comfort;
Darkness, and want of meat; alas she weeps too,
Which is the top of all my sorrows, Jertred.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No, no, you will not know me; my poor beauty,
Which has been worth your eyes.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: The time grows on still:
And like a tumbling wave, I see my ruin,
Come rolling over me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yet will ye know me?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For a hundred thousand crowns.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yet will ye love me?
Tell me but how I have deserved your slighting.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: For a hundred thousand crowns?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Farewell dissembler.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Of which I have scarce ten: o how it starts me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: And may the next you love, hearing my ruin.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I had forgotten myself, o my best Gertrud,
Crown of my joys, and comforts.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sweet what ail ye?
I thought you had been vexed with me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My mind wench,
My mind o'er flowed with sorrow, sunk my memory.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Am I not worthy of the knowledge of it?
And cannot I as well affect your sorrows,
As your delights? you love no other woman?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No I protest.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You have no ships lost lately?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: None that I know of.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I hope you have spilt no blood: whose innocence
May lay this on your conscience.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Clear, by heaven.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why should you be thus then?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Good Jertred, ask not,
E'en by the love you bear me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am obedient.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Go in my fair; I will not be long from ye,
Nor long I fear me with thee, at my return
Despise me as you please.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: The good gods guide ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Now for myself which is the least I hope for,
And when that fails, for man's worst fortune, pity. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why gentlemen, 'tis but a week more I entreat you
But 7. short days, I am not running from ye,
Nor, if you give me patience, is it possible
All my adventures fail; you have ships abroad,
Endure the beating both of wind, or weather:
I am sure 'twould vex your hearts, to be protested
Ye are all fair merchants,

sp.speaker: 1. Merchant
sp.l: Yes, and must have fair play;
There is no lying here else, one hours failing
Fails us of all our friends, of all our credits:
For my part I would stay; but my wants tell me,
I must wrong others in't.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No mercy in ye?

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant
sp.l: 'Tis foolish to depend on others mercy:
Keep yourself right, and even, out your cloth sir,
According to your calling: you have lived here
In lordlike prodigality; high, and open,
And now ye find what 'tis: the liberal spending
The summer of your youth, which you should glean in,
And like the labouring ant, make use and gain of,
Has brought this bitter stormy winter on ye,
And now you cry.

sp.speaker: 3. Merchant
sp.l: Alas before your poverty,
We were no men, of no mark, no endeavour;
You stood alone, took up all trade, all business,
Running through your hands, scarce a sail at sea,
But loaden with your goods: we poor weak pedlars,
When by your leave, and much entreaty to it:
We could have stowage for a little cloth,
Or a few wines, put of and thank your worship
Lord, how the world's changed with ye? now I hope sir,
We shall have sea-room

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is my misery,
Become my scorn too? have ye no humanity,
No part of men left? are all the bounties in me
To you, and to the town; turned my reproaches?

sp.speaker: 4. Merchant
sp.l: Well, get your money's ready: 'tis but 2. hours
We shall protest ye else, and suddenly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But two days.

sp.speaker: 1. Merchant
sp.l: Not an hour, ye know the hazard. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How soon my light's put out: hard hearted Bruges;
Within thy walls, may never honest merchant
Venture his fortunes more: o my poor wench too;

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Good fortune master.

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.l: Thou mistakest me clause,
I am not worth thy blessing.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: Still a sad man?
sp.stage: Enter Higgen. and Prig. like porter.
sp.l: No belief gentle master? come bring it in then,
And now believe your beadsman.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is this certain?
Or dost thou work upon my troubled sense?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis gold sir,
Take it and try it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Certainly 'tis treasure,
Can there be yet this blessing?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Cease your wonder,
You shall not sink, for never a soused flap-dragon:
For ne'er a pickled pilchard of 'em all sir,
'Tis there your full sum, a hundred thousand crowns,
And good sweet master, now be merry: pay 'em
Pay the poor pelting knaves, that know no goodness:
And cheer your heart up handsomely.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Good clause,
How cam'st thou by this mighty sum? if naughtily
I must not take it of thee, 'twill undo me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Fear not: you have it by as honest means
As though your father gave it: sir, you know not
