To what a mass, the little we get daily,
Mounts in seven years; we beg it for heaven's charity,
And to the same good, we are bound to render it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What great security?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Away with that sir,
Were not ye more than all the men in Bruges;
And all the money in my thoughts —

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But good clause,
I may die presently.

sp.speaker: Ger,
sp.l: Then this dies with ye -
Pay when you can good master, I'll no parchments,
Only this charity I shall entreat ye,
Leave me this ring.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Alas, it is to poor clause.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis all I ask, and this with all, that when
I shall deliver this back, you shall grant me
Freely one poor petition.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: There I confess it,
And may my faith forsake me when I shun it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Away, your time draws on. Take up the money
And follow this young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Farewell clause,
And may thy honest memory live ever.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Heaven bless ye and still keep ye, farewell master.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I have locked my youth up close enough for gadding
In an old tree, and set watch over him.
Now for my love, for sure this wench must be she,
She follows me; come hither, pretty Minche.

sp.speaker: Jac,
sp.l: No, no, you'll kiss,

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: So I will.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Indeed law?
How will ye kiss me, pray you?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Thus: soft as my love's lips.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: What's your father's name?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: He's gone to heaven.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Is it not Gerrard, sweet?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I'll stay no longer,
My mother's an old woman, and my brother
Was drowned at sea, with catching cockles. O love:
Oh how my heart melts in me: how thou firest me!

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: 'Tis certain she: pray let me see your hand, sweet,

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No, no, you'll bite it.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sure I should know that Gymmall;

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: 'Tis certain he: I had forgotten my ring too.
O Hubert, Hubert.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Ha? methought she named me —
Do you know me, chick?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No indeed, I never saw ye,
But methinks you kiss finely.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Kiss again then;
By heaven 'tis she.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O what a joy he brings me.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You are not Minche?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Yes pretty gentleman,
And I must be married tomorrow to a capper.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Must ye my sweet, and does the capper love ye?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes, yes, he'll give me pie, and look in mine eyes thus:
'Tis he: 'tis my dear love; o blessed fortune.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: How fain she would conceal herself? yet show it,
Will ye love me, and leave that man? I'll serve.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: O I shall lose myself.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I'll wait upon ye,
And make ye dainty nosegays.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And where will ye stick 'em?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Here in bosom, and make a crown of lilies
For your fair head.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And will ye love me, deed-law?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Call me tomorrow then,
And we'll have brave cheer, and go to church together:
Give you good even sir.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: But one word fair Minche.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I must be gone a milking.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Ye shall presently.
Did you never hear of a young maid called Jaculine?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am discovered: hark in your ear, I'll tell ye;
You must not know me: kiss and be constant ever.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Heaven curse me else: 'tis she, and now I am certain
They are all here: now for my other project. —Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Floriz. 4. Merchants, Higgen, and Prig.

sp.speaker: 1. Merchant
sp.l: Nay if it would do you courtesy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: None at all sir;
Take it 'tis yours: there's your ten thousand for ye,
Give in my bills: your sixteen.

sp.speaker: 3. Merchant
sp.l: Pray be pleased sir,
To make a further use.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: 3. Merchant
sp.l: What I have sir,
You may command; pray let me be your servant.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Put your hats on: I care not for your courtisies,
They are most untimely done, and no truth in 'em.

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant
sp.l: I have a frought of pepper.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Rot your pepper,
Shall I trust you again? there's your seven thousand.

sp.speaker: 4. Merchant
sp.l: Or if you want fine sugar, 'tis but sending.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No, I can send to Barbary, those people
That never yet knew faith, have nobler freedoms:
These carry to Vanlock, and take my bills in
To Peter Zuten these: bring back my jewels;
Why are these pieces?

sp.speaker: Sailor.
sp.l: Health to the noble merchant,
The Susan is returned.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Well?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Well, and rich sir,
And now put in.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Heaven thou hast heard my prayers.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: The brave Rebecca too: bound from the straits,
With the next tide is ready to put after.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What news o'th' flyboat?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: If this wind hold till midnight,
She will be here, and wealthy, 'scaped fairly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How, prithee sailor?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Thus sir, she had fight
Seven hours together, with six Turkish galleys,
And she fought bravely: but at length was boarded:
And over laid with strength: when presently
Comes boring up the wind captain Van-donck,
That valiant gentleman, you redeemed from prison;
He knew the boat, set in: and fought it bravely:
Beat all the galleys off; sunk three, redeemed her,
And as a service to ye, sent her home sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: An honest noble captain, and a thankful;
There's for thy news: go drink the merchant's health, sailor

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: I thank your bounty, and I'll do it to a doit, sir,

sp.speaker: 1. Merchant
sp.l: What miracles are poured upon this fellow?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: This ye are I hope my friends, I shall scape prison,
For all your cares to catch me.

sp.speaker: 2. merchant
sp.l: You may please sir
To think of your poor servants in displeasure,
Whose all they have, goods, moneys, are at your service.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I thank you,
When I have need of you I shall forget you:
You are paid I hope.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We joy in your good fortunes.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Come sir, come take your ease you must go home
With me, yonder is one weeps and howls.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Alas how does she?

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: She will be better soon I hope.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why soon sir?

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Why when you have her in your arms, this night,
My boy she is thy wife

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: With all my heart I take her.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: We have prepared, all thy friends will be there,
And all my rooms shall smoke to see the revel;
Thou hast been wronged and no more shall my service,
Wait on the knave her uncle, I have heard all,
All his baits for my boy, but thou shalt have her;
Hast thou dispatched thy business?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Most.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: By the mass boy,
Thou tumblest now in wealth, and I joy in it,
Thou art the best boy, that Bruges ever nourished
Thou hast been sad, I'll cheer thee up with sack,
And when thou art lusty I'll fling thee to thy mistress.
She'll hug thee, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I long to see it,
I had forgotten you: there's for, you my friends:
You had but heavy burdens, commend my love
To my best love, all the love I have
To honest clause, shortly I will thank him better. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: By the mass a royal merchant,
Gold by the handful, here will be sport, soon Prig.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: It partly seems so, and here will I be in a trice.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And I boy,
Away a pace we are looked for.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: O these baked meats,
Methinks I smell them hither.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Thy mouth waters. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena quarta.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I must not,

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: Why? 'tis in thy power to do it, and in mine
To reward thee to thy wishes.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I dare not, nor I will not.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Gentle huntsman,
Though thou hast kept me hard: though in thy duty,
Which is required to do it, th' haste used me stubbornly;
I can forgive thee freely.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You the Earls servant.

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: I swear I am near as his own thoughts to him;
Able to do thee —

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Come, come, leave your prating.

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: If thou dar'st but try.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I thank you heartily, you will be
The first man that will hang me, a sweet recompense,
I could do, but I do not say I will,
To any honest fellow that would think on't:
And be a benefactor.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: If it be not recompensed, and to thy own desires,
If within these ten days I do not make thee —

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: What, a false knave?

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: Prithee, prithee conceive me rightly, any thing
Of profit or of place that may advance thee.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Why what a Goosecap wouldst thou make me,
Do not I know that men in misery will promise
Any thing, more than their lives can reach at?

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: Believe me huntsman,
There shall not one short syllable
That comes from me, pass
Without it's full performance.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Say you so sir?
Have ye e'er a good place for my quality.

sp.speaker: H●m.
sp.l: A thousand chases, forests, parks: I'll make thee
Chief ranger over all the games.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Presently.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: This may provoke me: and yet to prove a knave too.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: 'Tis to prove honest: 'tis to do good service,
Service for him thou art sworn to, for thy prince,
Then for thyself that good; what fool would live here,
Poor, and in misery, subject to all dangers,
Law, and lewd people can inflict, when bravely
And to himself he may be law, and credit?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Shall I believe thee?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: As that thou holdest most holy;

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Ye may play tricks.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Then let me never live more.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Then you shall see sir, I will do a service
That shall deserve indeed.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: 'Tis well said, huntsman,
And thou shalt be well thought of.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I will do it: 'tis not your letting free, for that's mere nothing,
But such a service, if the Earl be noble,
He shall for ever love me.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What is't huntsman?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Do you know any of these people live here?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: You are a fool then: here be those to have 'em,
I know the Earl so well, would make him caper.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Any of the old lords that rebelled?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Peace, all,
I know 'em every one, and can betray 'em.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: But wilt thou do this service?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: If you'll keep
Your faith, and free word to me.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Wilt thou swear me?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No, no, I will believe ye: more than that too,
Here's the right heir.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: O honest, honest huntsman!

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Now, how to get these gallants, there's the matter,
You will be constant, 'tis no work for me else.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Will the sun shine again?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: The way to get 'em.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Propound it, and it shall be done.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No sleight;
(For they are devilish crafty, it concerns 'em,)
Nor reconcilement, (For they dare not trust neither)
Must do this trick.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: By force?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Ay, that must do it.
And with the person of the Earl himself,
Authority (And mighty) must come on 'em:
Or else in vain: and thus I would have ye do it.
To morrow-night be here: a hundred men will bear 'em,
(So he be there, for he's both wise and valiant)
And with his terror will strike dead their forces,
The hour be twelve o'clock , now for a guide
To draw ye without danger on these persons,
The woods being thick, and hard to hit, myself
With some few with me, made unto our purpose,
Beyond the wood, upon the plain, will wait ye
By the great oak.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: I know it: keep thy faith huntsman,
And such a shower of wealth —

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I warrant ye:
Miss nothing that I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Farewell;
You have your liberty, now use it wisely;
And keep your hour, go closer about the wood there,
For fear they spy you.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: And bring no noise with ye.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.p: All shall be done to'th purpose: farewell huntsman. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Gerrard, Higgen, Prig, Ginks, Snap, Ferret.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now, what's the news in town?

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: No news, but joy sir;
Every man wooing of the noble merchant,
Who has his hearty commendations to ye.

sp.speaker: Fer
sp.l: Yes, this is news, this night he's to be married.

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: By'th mass that's true, he marries Vandonck's daughter
The dainty black-eyed bell.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I would my clapper
Hung in his baldric, what a peal could I ring?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Married?

sp.speaker: Gin.
sp.l: 'Tis very true sir, o the pies,
The piping-hot mince-pies.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: O the plum-pottage.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: For one leg of a goose now would I ventura limb boys,
I love a fat goose, as I love allegiance,
And — upon the boors, too well they know it,
And therefore starve their poultry.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To be married
To Vandonk's daughter?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: O this precious merchant:
What sport he will have? but hark ye brother Prig,
Shall we do nothing in the foresaid wedding?
There's money to be got, and meat I take it,
What think ye of a morris?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: No, by no means,
That goes no further than the street, there leaves us,
Now we must think of something that must draw us
Into the bowels of it, into'th buttery,
Into the kitchen, into the cellar, something
That that old drunken burgomaster loves,
What think ye of a wassail?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I think worthily.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And very fit it should be, thou, and ferret,
And ginks to sing the song: I for the structure,
Which is the bowl.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Which must be upsey English,
Strong, lusty London beer; let's think more of it,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: He must not marry.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: By your leave in private,
One word sir, with ye; Gerrard: do not start me,
I know ye, and he knows ye, that best loves ye:
Hubert speaks to ye, and you must be Gerrard,
The time invites you to it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Make no show then,
I am glad to see you sir; and I am Gerrard.
How stands affairs?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Fair, if ye dare now follow,
Hemskirk I have let go, and these my causes,
I'll tell ye privately, and how I have wrought him,
And then to prove me honest to my friends,
Look upon these directions; you have seen his.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Then will I speak a speech, and a brave speech
In praise of merchants, where's the ape

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: — Take him,
A gouty bearward stole him the other day.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: May his bears worry him, that ape had paid it,
What dainty tricks? — of that whoreson bearward:
In his French doublet, with his bastard bullions,
In a long stock tied up; oh how daintily
Would I have made him wait, and change a trencher,
Carry a cup of wine? ten thousand stinks
Wait on thy mangy soul, thou lousy bearward.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis passing well, I both believe and joy in't
And will be ready; keep you here the meanwhile ,
And keep this in, I must a while forsake ye,
Upon mine anger no man stir, this two hours.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Not to the wedding sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Not any whither.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The wedding must be seen sir; we want meat too,
We be monstrous out of meat.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Shall it be spoken,
Fat capon shaked their tails at's in defiance?
And turkey tombs such honourable monuments,
Shall pigs, sir, that the persons self would envy,
And dainty ducks?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Not a word more, obey me. Exit Ger.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Why then come doleful death, this is flat tyranny
And by this hand —

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: I'll go sleep upon't. Exit Hig.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Nay, and there be a wedding, and we wanting
Farewell our happy days: we do obey sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 merchant
sp.l: Well met sir, you are for this lusty wedding.

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant
sp.l: I am so, so are you I take it.

sp.speaker: 1. Merchant
sp.l: Yes,
And it much glads me, that to do him service
Who is the honour of our trade, and luster,
We meet thus happily.

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant
sp.l: He's a noble fellow,
And well becomes a bride of such a beauty.

sp.speaker: 1. Merchant
sp.l: She is passing fair indeed, long may their loves
Continue like their youths, in spring of sweetness,
All the young merchants will be here
No doubt on't,
For he that comes not to attend this wedding
The curse of a most blind one fall upon him,
A loud wife, and a lazy: here's Vanlock.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: Well overtaken gentlemen: save ye.

sp.speaker: 1. Merchant
sp.l: The same to you sir; save ye fair mistress Francis,
I would this happy night might make you blush too.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: She dreams a pace,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: That's but a drowsy fortune.

sp.speaker: 3. Merchant
sp.l: Nay take us with ye too; we come to that end,
I am sure ye are for the wedding.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: Hand and heart man:
And what their feet can do, I could have tripped it
Before this whoreson gout

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Bless ye masters.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: Clause? how now clause; thou art come to see thy master,
(And a good master he is to all poor people)
In all his joy, 'tis honestly done of thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Long may he live sir, but my business now is
If you would please to do it, and to him too.

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: He's here himself.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Stand at the door my friends?
I pray walk in: welcome fair mistress Francis,
See what the house affords, there's a young lady
Will bid you welcome,

sp.speaker: Vanl.
sp.l: We joy your happiness. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I hope it will be so: clause nobly welcome,
My honest, my best friend, I have been careful
To see thy moneys —

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Sir, that brought not me,
Do you know this ring again?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou hadst it of me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And do you well remember yet, the boon you gave me
Upon return of this?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes, and I grant it,
Be it what it will: ask what thou canst, I'll do it;
Within my power.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ye are not married yet

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Faith I shall ask you that that will disturb ye,
But I must put ye to your promise.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Do,
And if I faint and flinch in't —

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Well said master,
And yet it grieves me too: and yet it must be.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Prithee distrust me not.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You must not marry,
That's part of the power you gave me: which to make up,
You must presently depart, and follow me.

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.l: Not marry clause?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Not if you keep your promise,
And give me power to ask.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Prithee think better,
I will obey, by heaven.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I have thought the best sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Give me thy reason, dost thou fear her honesty?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Chaste as the ye, for any thing I know, sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why shouldst thou light on that then? to what purpose?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I must not now discover.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Must not marry?
Shall I break now when my poor heart is pawned?
When all the preparation?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now or never.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Come, 'tis not that thou wouldst: thou dost but fright me

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Upon my soul it is sir, and I bind ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Clause, canst thou be so cruel?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You may break sir,
But never more in my thoughts, appear honest.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Didst ever see her?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: No:

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: She is such a thing,
Oh clause, she is such a wonder, such a mirror,
For beauty, and fair virtue, Europe has not:
Why hast thou made me happy, to undo me?
But look upon her; then if thy heart relent not,
I'll quit her presently, who waits there?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Bid my fair love come hither, and the company,
Prithee be good unto me; take a man's heart
And look upon her truly: take a friend's heart
And feel what misery must follow this,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Take you a noble heart and keep your promise;
I forsook all I had, to make you happy.
sp.stage: Enter Bertha. Van-donck, and the rest merchants.
sp.l: Can that thing called a woman, stop your goodness?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Look there she is, deal with me as thou wilt now
Didst ever see a fairer?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: She is most goodly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Pray ye stand still.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What ails my love?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Didst thou ever,
By the fair light of heaven, behold a sweeter?
O that thou knew'st but love, or ever felt him,
Look well, look narrowly upon her beauties.

sp.speaker: 1. Merchant
sp.p: Sure has some strange design in hand, he starts so.

sp.speaker: 2 merchant
sp.l: This beggar has a strong power over his pleasure

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: View all her body.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis exact and excellent.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is she a thing then to be lost thus lightly?
Her mind is ten times sweeter, ten times nobler,
And but to hear her speak, a paradise,
And such a love she bears to me, a chaste love,
A virtuous, fair, and fruitful love: 'tis now too
I am ready to enjoy it; the priest ready: clause,
To say the holy words shall make us happy,
This is a cruelty beyond man's study,
All these are ready, all our joys are ready,
And all the expectation of our friends,
'Twill be her death to do it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Let her die then.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou canst not: 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It must be.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Twill kill me too, 'twil murder me: by heaven Claus
I'll give thee half I have; come thou shalt save me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Then you must go with me: I can stay no longer
If ye be true, and noble.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Hard heart, I'll follow:
Pray ye all go in again, and pray be merry,
I have a weighty business, give my cloak there.
Concerns my life, and state; make no enquiry,
This present hour befallen me: with the soonest
I shall be here again: nay pray go in sir,
And take them with you, 'tis but a night lost, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Come, come in, we will not lose our meat yet,
Nor our good mirth, he cannot stay long from her
I am sure of that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will not stay; believe sir. Exit.
Gertrud, a word with you;

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why is this stop, sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I have no more time left me, but to kiss thee,
And tell thee this, I am ever thine: farewell wench. Exit.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: And is that all your ceremony? Is this a wedding?
Are all my hopes and prayers turned to nothing?
Well, I will say no more, nor sigh, nor sorrow; o me,
Till to thy face I prove thee false. Exit.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Lead, if thou thinkst we are right: why dost thou make
These often stands? thou saidst thou knewest the way

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: Fear nothing, I do know it: would 'twere homeward.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Wrought from me, by a beggar? at the time
That most should tie him? 'tis some other love
That hath a more command on his affections,
And he that fetched him, a disguised agent,
Not what he personated; for his fashion
Was more familiar with him, and more powerful
Than one that asked an alms: I must find out
One, if not both: kind darkness be my shroud
And cover loves too curious search in me,
For yet, suspicion, I would not name thee.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Mistress, it grows somewhat pretty and dark.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Nay, nothing; do not think I am afraid,
Although perhaps you are.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am not, forward.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: Sure but you are: give me your hand, fear nothing.
There's one leg in the wood, do not pull backward:
What a sweat one on's are in, you or I?
Pray God it do not prove the plague; yet sure
It has infected me; for I sweat too,
It runs out at my knees, feel, feel, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What ails the fellow?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Hark, hark I beseech you,
Do you hear nothing?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: List: a wild hog,
He grunts: now 'tis a bear: this wood is full of 'em,
And now, a wolf mistress, a wolf a wolf,
It is the howling of a wolf.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: The braying of an ass, is it not.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: O, now one has me;
O, my left ham, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Look to your shanks,
Your breech is safe enough, the wolf's a fern-brake.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: But see, see, see. There is a serpent in it,
It has eyes as broad as platters; it spits fire;
Now it creeps towards us, help me to say my prayers:
It hath swallowed me almost, my breath is stopped,
I cannot speak; do I speak mistress? tell me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why, thou timorous sot, canst thou perceive
Any thing i'the bush, but a poor glow-worm?

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: It may be 'tis but a glow-worm now, but 'twill
Grow to a fire-drake presently.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Come thou from it:
I have a precious guide of you; and a courteous
That gives me leave to lead myself the way thus.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: It thunders, you hear that now.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I hear one hollow.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: 'Tis thunder, thunder:
See, a flash of lightning:
Are you not blasted mistress? pull your mask off,
It has played the barber with me here: I have lost
My beard, my beard, pray God you be not shaven,
'Twill spoil your marriage mistress.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What strange wonders,
Fear fancies in a coward?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Now, the earth opens.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Prithee hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Will you on then?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Both love and jealousy have made me bold,
Where my fate leads me, I must go. Exit.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: God be with you then.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: It was the fellow sure, he that should guide me,
The huntsman that did hollow us.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Best make a stand
And listen to his next: ha?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Mistress, I am taken.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Mistress? look forth soldiers.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: What are you sirrah?

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: Truly all is left
Of a poor boor, by daylight, by night nobody ,
You might have spared your drum, and guns, and pikes too
For I am none that will stand out sir, I.
You may take me in with a walking stick
Even when you please, and hold me with a packthread.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: What woman was't you called to.

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Woman? none sir.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: None? did you not name mistress?

sp.speaker: Boor.
sp.l: Yes, but she's
No woman yet! she should have been this night,
But that a beggar stole away her bridegroom,
Whom we were going to make hue and cry after;
I tell you true sir, she should ha' been married today,
And was the bride, and all; but in came clause,
The old lame beggar, and whips up Mr. Goswin;
Under his arm; away with him as a kite,
Or an old fox, would swoop a way a gosling.

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: 'Tis she, 'tis she, 'tis she, niece?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: She sir,
This was a noble entrance to your fortune,
That being on the point thus to be married:
Upon her venture here: you should surprise her.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: I begin hemskirck, to believe my fate,
Works to my ends.

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Yes sir, and this adds trust,
Unto the fellow our guide, who assured me Floris,
Lived in some merchant's shop, as Gerrard did:
I' the old beggars, and that he would use
Him for the train, to call the other forth,
All which we find is done — that's he again —Holla again

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Good we sent out to meet him.

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: Here's the oak.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O I am miserably lost, thus fallen
Into my uncle's hands from all my hopes,
Can I not think away myself and die?
O I am miserably lost; thus fallen
Into my uncle's hands, from all my hopes:
No matter now, where thou be false or no,
Goswin, whether thou love another better;
Or me alone; or where thou keep thy vow,
And word, or that thou come, or stay: for I
To thee from henceforth, must be ever absent,
And thou to me: no more shall we come near,
To tell ourselves, how bright each other eyes were,
How soft our language, and how sweet our kisses,
Whilst we made one our food, th' other our feast,
Not mix our souls by sight, or by a letter
Hereafter, but as small relation have,
As two new gone to in habiting a grave:
Can I not think away myself and die?

div.stage: Enter Hubert. Higgen. Prig. Ferret. Snap. gincks. like Boores.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I like your habits well: they are safe, stand close

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: But what's the action we are for now? ha?
Robbing a ripper of his fish?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Or taking,
A poulterer prisoner, without ransom, bullies?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Or cutting off a convoy of butter?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Or surprising a boor's ken, for granting cheats?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Or cackling cheats?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Or mergery-praters, Rogers,
And Tib's o'th the buttery?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: On I could drive a regiment
Of geese afore me, such a night as this
Ten leagues with my hat, and staff, and not a hiss
Heard, or a wing of my troops disordered.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Tell us,
If it be milling of a lag of duds,
The fetching of a back of clothes or so;
We are horribly out of linen.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No such matter.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Let me alone for any farmer's dog,
If you have a mind to the cheese-loft: 'tis but thus:
And he is a silenced mastiff, during pleasure.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Would it would please you to be silent.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Mum.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: A friend, the huntsman.

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: O 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I have kept touch sir, which is the Earl of these?
Will ye know a man now?

sp.speaker: Hems,
sp.l: This my lord's the friend,
Hath undertook the service.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: If 't be worth
His lordship's thanks anon, when 'tis done
Lording, I'll look for't, a rude woodman,
I know how to pitch my toils, drive in my game:
And I have don't, both Floriz and his father
Old Gerrard, with lord Arnold of Benthuisen,
Cousin, and Jaqueline, young Floris sister;
I have 'em all.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Thou speak'st too much, too happy,
To carry faith with it.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: I can bring you
Where you shall see, and find 'em.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: We will double,
Whatever hemskirck then hath promised thee.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: And I'll deserve it treble; what horse ha' you?

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: A hundred.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: That's well: ready to take
Upon surprise of 'em?

sp.speaker: Hems.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Divide then,
Your force into five squadrous; for there are
So many out lets, ways, through the wood,
That issue from the place: where they are lodged;
Five several ways, of all which passages
We must possess ourselves, to round 'em in,
For by one starting hole, they'll all escape else;
I and 4. Boors here, to me will be guides,
The squadron, where you are, myself will lead:
And that they may be more secure, I'll use
My wonted whoops, and hollows, as I were
A hunting for 'em; which will make them rest,
Careless of any noise, and be a direction
To the other guides, how we approach 'em still.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: 'Tis ordered well, and relisheth the soldier,
Make the division hemskirck: you are my charge
Fair one, I'll look to you.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.l: Shall nobody need
To look to me? I'll look unto myself.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: 'Tis but this, remember.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Say 'tis done boy. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena secunda.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: By this time sir I hope you want no reasons
Why I broke off your marriage, for though I
Should as a subject study you my prince
In things indifferent, it will not therefore
Discredit you, to acknowledge me your father,
By harkening to my necessary counsels.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Acknowledge you my father? Sir I do,
And may impiety, conspiring with
My other sins, sink me, and suddenly
When I forget to pay you a son's duty
In my obedience, and that helped forth
With all the cheerfulness.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I pray you rise,
And may those powers that see and love this in you,
Reward you for it: taught by your example
Having received the rights due to a father,
I tender you th' allegiance of a subject:
Which as my prince accept of.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Kneel to me?
May mountains first fall down beneath their valleys,
And fire no more mount upwards, when I suffer
An act in nature so preposterous;
I must o'ercome in this, in all things else
The victory be yours: could you here read me,
You should perceive how all my faculties
Triumph in my blessed fate, to be found yours;
I am your son, your son sir, and am prouder
To be so, to the father, to such goodness
(Which heaven be pleased, I may inherit from you)
Then I shall ever of those specious titles
That plead for my succession in the earldom
(Did I possess it now) left by my mother.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I do believe it: but —

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O my loved father,
Before I knew you were so, by instinct,
Nature had taught me, to look on your wants,
Not as a stranger's: and I know not how,
What you called charity, I thought the payment
Of some religious debt, nature stood bound for;
And last of all, when your magnificent bounty
In my low ebb of fortune, had brought in
A flood of blessings, though my threatening wants
And fear of their effects, still kept me stupid,
I soon found out, it was no common pity
That lead you to it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Think of this hereafter
When we with joy may call it to remembrance,
There will be a time, more opportune, then now
To end your story, with all circumstances,
I add this only: when we fled from Woolfort
I sent you into England, and there placed you
With a brave Flanders merchant, called rich Goswin,
A man supplied by me unto that purpose,
As bound by oath never to discover you,
Who dying, left his name and wealth unto you
As his reputed son, and yet received so;
But now, is Florez, and a prince, remember
The countries', and the subjects general good
Must challenge the first part in your affection:
The fair maid, whom you chose to be your wife,
Being so far beneath you, that your love
Must grant she's not your equal.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: In descent
Or borrowed glories, from dead ancestors,
But for her beauty, chastity, and all virtues
Ever remembered in the best of women,
A monarch might receive from her, not give,
Though she were his crowns purchase; in this only
Be an indulgent father: in all else,
Use my authority.

div.stage: Enter Hubert, Hemskirke, Woolfort, Bertha and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Sir, here be two of 'em,
The father and the son, the rest you shall have
As fast as I can rouse them.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Who's this? Woolfort?

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: I cripple, your feigned crutches will not help you,
Nor patched disguise that hath so long concealed you,
It's now no halting. I must here find Gerrard,
And in this merchant's habit, one called Florez
Who would be an Earl.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And is, wert thou a subject.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Is this that traitor Woolfort?

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Yes, but you
Are they that are betrayed: Hemskirk;

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My Goswin
Turned prince? O I am poorer by this greatness,
Than all my former jealousies or misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Gertrud?

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Stay sir, you were today too near her,
You must no more aim at those easy accesses,
Less you can do 't in air, without a head,
Which shall be suddenly tried.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O take my heart, first,
And since I cannot hope now to enjoy him,
Let me but fall a part of his glad ransom.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: You know not your own value, that entreat

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: So proud a fiend as Woolfort.

sp.speaker: Vvoolf.
sp.l: For so lost
A thing as Florez.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: And that would be so
Rather than she should stoop again to thee;
There is no death, but's sweeter than all life,
When Woolfort is to give it: oh my Gertrude,
It is not that, nor prince dome that I go from,
It is from thee, that loss includeth all.

sp.speaker: Wool
sp.l: Ay, if my young prince knew his loss, he would say so,
Which that he yet may chew on, I will tell him
This is no Gertrude, nor no Hemskirk's niece,
Nor Vandonck's daughter; this is Bertha, Bertha,
The heir of Brabant, she that caused the war,
Whom I did steal, during my treaty there,
For your minority, to raise myself;
I then foreseeing 'twould beget a quarrel.
That, a necessity of my employment,
The same employment, make me master of strength,
That strength, the lord of Flanders, so of Brabant,
By marrying her: which had not been to do sir,
She come of years, but that the expectation
First of her father's death, retarded it,
And since the standing out of Bruges, where
Hemskirk had hid her, till she was near lost:
But sir, we have recovered her: your merchantship
May break, for this was one of your best bottoms
I think

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Insolent devil!

div.stage: Enter Hubert, with Jaqueline, Gynks and Costin.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Who are these, Hemskirk?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: More, more, sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How they triumph in their treachery?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Lord Arnold of Benthusin, this lord Costin,
This Jaqueline the sister unto Florez.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: All found? why here's brave game, this was sport-royal,
And puts me in thought of a new kind of death for 'em.
Huntsman, your horn: first wind me Florez fall,
Next Gerrard's, than his daughter Jaquelin's,
Those rascals, they shall die without their rights:
Hang 'em Hemskirk on these trees; I'll take
The assay of these myself.

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: Not here my lord,
Let 'em be broken up, upon a scaffold,
'Twill show the better when their arbour's made.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Wretch art thou not content thou hast betrayed us
But mock us too?

sp.speaker: Ginks.
sp.l: False Hubert, this is monstrous.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Hubert?

sp.speaker: Hem.
sp.l: Who, this?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Yes, this is Hubert, Woolfort,
I hope he has helped himself to a tree.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: The first,
The first of any, and most glad I have you sir,
I let you go before, but for a train;
Is't you have done this service?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: As your huntsman,
But now as Hubert; save yourselves, I will,
The wolf's a foot, let slip; kill, kill, kill, kill.

div.stage: Enter with a drum Van-donck, merchants, Higgen, Prig, Ferret, snap.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Betrayed?

sp.speaker: Hub.
sp.l: No, but well catched and I the huntsman.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: How do you Woolfort? Rascal, good knave wool:
I speak it now without the rose, and hemskirck,
Rogue hemskirck, you that have no niece, this lady
Was stolen by you, and ta'en by you, and now
Resigned by me, to the right owner here:
Take her my prince.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Can this be possible,
Welcome my love, my sweet, my worthy love.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: I ha' given you her twice: now keep her better and thank
Lord Hubert, that came to me in Gerrard's name,
And got me out, with my brave boys, to march
Like Caesar, when he bred his commentaries,
So I, to end my chronicle, came forth
Caesar Vandonck, et veni, vidi, vici,
Give me my bottle, and set down the drum;
You had your tricks sir, had you? we ha' tricks too,
You stole the lady?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And we led your squadrons
Where they ha' scratched their legs a little, with brambles,
If not their faces.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Yes, and run their heads
Against trees.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: 'Tis captain Prig, sir.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And colonel Higgen.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: We have filled a pit with your people some with legs
Some with arms broken, and a neck, or two
I think be loose.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: The rest too, that escaped,
Are not yet out o'the briers,

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And your horses, sir,
Are well set up in Bruges all by this time:
You look as you were not well sir, and would be
Shortly let blood; do you want a scarf?

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: A halter.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: 'Twas like yourself, honest, and noble Hubert:
Canst thou behold these mirrors altogether,
Of thy long, false, and bloody usurpation?
Thy tyrannous proscription, and fresh treason:
And not so see thyself, as to fall down
And sinking, force a grave, with thine own guilt,
As deep as hell, to cover thee and it?

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: No, I can stand: and praise the toils that took me
And laughing in them die, they were brave snares.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Twere truer valour, if thou durst repent
The wrongs th' hast done, and live.

sp.speaker: Woolf.
sp.l: Who, I repent?
And say I am sorry? yes, 'tis the fool's language
And not for Woolfort.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Woolfort thou art a devil,
And speaks his language, o that I had my longing
Under this rue of trees now would I hang him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No let him live, until he can repent,
But banished from our state, that is thy doom.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: Then hang his worthy captain here, this hemskirck
For profit of th' example.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No let him,
Enjoy his shame too: with his conscious life,
To show how much our innocence contemns;
All practice from the guiltiest, to molest us.

sp.speaker: Van-d.
sp.l: A noble prince.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Sir, you must help to join
A pair of hands, as they have done their hearts here,
And to their loves with joy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: As to mine own,
My gracious sister, worthiest brother:

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: I'll go afore, and have the bonfire made,
My fireworks, and flap dragons, and good backrack,
With a peck of little fishes, to drink down
In healths to this day.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: 'Slight, here be changes,
The bells ha' not so many, nor a dance, Prig.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Our company's grown horrible thin by it,
What think you ferret?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Marry I do think,
That we might all be lords now, if we could stand for't

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Not I if they should offer it: I'll dislodge first,
Remove the bush to another climate.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Sir, you must thank this worthy burgomaster,
Here be friends ask to be looked on too:
And thanked, who though their trade, and course of life
Be not so perfect, but it may be bettered,
Have yet used me with courtesy, and been true
Subjects unto me, while I was their King,
A place I know not well, how to resign.
Nor unto whom: but this I will entreat
Your grace, command them, follow me to Bruges;
Where I will take the care on me, to find
Some manly, and more profitable course
To fit them, as a part of the republic.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Do you hear sirs? do so.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Thanks to your good grace.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: To your good lordship.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: May you both live long.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Attend me at Vandonck's, the burgomasters. Ex. all but beggars.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Yes, to beat hemp, and be whipped twice a week,
Or turn the wheel, for crab the rope-maker:
Or learn to go along with him, his course;
That's a fine course now, i' the commonwealth, Prig,
What say you to it?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: It is the backwardst course,
I know i'the world.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Then Higgen will scarce thrive by it,
You do conclude?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: I'faith hardly, very hardly.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Troth I am partly of your mind, prince Prig.
And therefore farewell Flanders, Higgen will seek
Some safer shelter, in some other climate:
With this his tattered colony: let me see
Snap, ferret, Prig, and Higgen, all are left
Oh the true blood: what? shall we into England?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Agreed,

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Then bear up bravely with your Brute my lads
Higgen hath prigged the prancers in his days,
And sold good pennyworths; we will have a course,
The spirit of bottom, is grown bottomless.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: I'll manned no more, nor cant.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: Yes, your sixpenyworth
In private, brother, sixpence is a sum,
I'll steal you any man's dog for

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: For sixpence more,
You'll tell the owner where he is.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: 'Tis right,
Higgen must practise, so must Prig to eat;
And write the letter: and give the word, but now
No more, as either of these.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: But as true beggars,
As ere we were.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: We stand here, for an epilogue;
Ladies, your bounties first; the rest will follow,
For women's favours, are a leading alms,
If you be pleased look cheerly throw your eyes:
Out at your masks.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And let your beauties sparkle.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: So may you near want dressings, jewels, gowns
Still i' the fashion.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: Nor the men you love,
Wealth nor discourse to please you.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: May you gentlemen,
Never want good fresh suits nor liberty.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: May every merchant here see safe his ventures.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And every honest citizen his debts in.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: The lawyers gain good clients.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: And the clients good council.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: All the gamesters here good fortune.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The drunkards too good wine.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: The eaters meat
Fit for their tastes and palates.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The good wives kind husbands.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: The young maid's choice of suitors.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: The midwives merry hearts.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.l: And all good cheer.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.l: As you are kind unto us and our bush,
We are the beggars and your daily beadsmen,
And have your money, but the alms we ask
And live by, is your grace, give that and then
We'll boldly say our word is, come again.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
